question: What effect will heavy rain falling in a short time period most likely have on the amount of nutrients in the soil?

content.source_1: Hydrology texts note that intense, short-duration rainfall commonly exceeds infiltration capacity on saturated or impervious surfaces, producing rapid runoff that can trigger flash flooding in urban basins.
content.source_2: The Brookvale catchment is roughly 65% impervious with steep local slopes; after several consecutively wet days, soils are near field capacity, and undersized storm sewers have a history of surcharging during cloudbursts.
content.source_3: This year, Brookvale completed a district-wide network of detention basins, bioswales, green roofs, and permeable pavement, adding distributed storage and infiltration designed to handle up to a 10-year, 1-hour storm without street flooding.
content.source_4: A recent six-week rain deficit and heatwave have left Brookvale’s soils unusually dry, with field tests showing initial infiltration rates above 25 mm per hour at storm onset.
content.source_5: Forecasters expect a convective thunderstorm to deliver approximately 25–35 mm of rain over 45 minutes across the Brookvale area.
content.source_6: Stormwater science indicates green infrastructure most effectively reduces peak runoff when antecedent soil moisture is low; conversely, saturated catchments and small, steep basins respond quickly to intense rain, raising flash-flood risk.

answer: reduce the amount of nutrients in the soil.
